thread.title: Kam Chancellor, defense save Seahawks in 13-10 win over winless Lions
thread.title_full: Kam Chancellor, defense save Seahawks in 13-10 win over winless Lions

author:
Gregg Bell 
Staff writer
title: Kam Chancellor, defense save Seahawks in 13-10 win over winless Lions
text:
October 5, 2015 Kam Chancellor, defense save Seahawks in 13-10 win over winless Lions As Lions receiver Calvin Johnson stretches for the end zone, Seahawks safety Kam Chancellor prepares to punch the ball loose in the waning moments of the fourth quarter. Photo taken in Seattle on Monday, Oct. 5, 2015. Drew Perine Staff photographer i 
The Seahawks were saved by a touchback in the "Fail Mary" end zone. 
Oh, and … Welcome back, Kam Chancellor. 
Seattle’s beloved team leader and Pro Bowl strong safety, 11 days removed from a two-month holdout, Megatron’d Detroit receiver Calvin Johnson off both his feet following a catch over the middle. Later in the fourth quarter, Chancellor saved the game. 
Former Seahawk Golden Tate kept the Lions alive with a big catch on third down late. But then Chancellor hit Johnson just before he carried a catch across the goal line with 1:51 left. That turned what would have been Detroit’s winning touchdown into the saving touchback, a fumble out of the back of the same, north end zone in which Tate simultaneously catch a desperation pass to end a Monday night win over the Packers in 2012. 
The defense not allowing an offensive touchdown for the second straight week – plus a clinching, 50-yard completion from harassed Russell Wilson to Jermaine Kearse – is how the Seahawks won their second straight game 13-10 over the Lions on another zany Monday night at CenturyLink Field. 
But can these Seahawks keep winning this way? 
It worked – barely – against Detroit (0-4, the league’s only winless team), this reliance on a back-to-form defense. Seattle pounded Lion after Lion and left him withering into the turf injured or stunned, or both. 
On offense, Wilson ran around making playground plays behind an awful offensive line while avoiding six more sacks than the four he got in front of 69,005 somewhat unsatisfied home fans. 
The Seahawks (2-2) played for just the second time in six seasons without Marshawn Lynch. He was out with an injured hamstring, though looked good running on the field two hours before kickoff. That was a positive sign he may be ready to return on Sunday when Seattle plays at unbeaten Cincinnati. 
The offense managed just one touchdown without the NFL’s rushing leader since 2011. Undrafted rookie Thomas Rawls led Seattle with 48 yards on 10 carries replacing Lynch. 
Wilson got sacked six times by a team that was 24 th in the 32-team league in sacks per game coming in. Wilson lost two fumbles. Detroit’s Caraun Reid scooped up the second one and ran 27 yards for the touchdown early in the fourth quarter. Suddenly, Seattle’s lead was down to 13-10, and the offense’s woes got further magnified. 
After yet another Seahawks’ three-and-out on offense, Detroit drove from its own 9 to the red zone. Then Chancellor saved the night.
